ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a deep understanding about how Russian became the country it is today
I was able to attain a very nuanced understanding of Russian Political Science and how the systems that drive it today developed over time.

I learned a lot more about Russian history and how it has influenced Putin's Russia we see today! Russia has a really fascinating history that requires more than just one course to fully learn about but I really learned a lot in this class that starts you out on a good path towards learning more in the future.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths were lots of engagement, interesting lectures and nice discussions. There were no weaknesses
Professor Lazarev did a great job highlighting informative and interesting topics.

The professor was incredibly smart, he knew everything about any conflict in the world we brought up in class (not just Russia) which helped make class engaging. The readings were also really interesting. The only possible weakness is that I wish we had more discussion questions about the readings since there were a few readings per week that covered a lot of material and was hard to talk about with an open-ended question asking for thoughts or comparisons between readings.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Splitting the class into half lecture half seminar made learning under covid feel better

I liked how classes were recorded. One thing that could help (especially since this was a small seminar) would be to have meetings with the professor to discuss essays and how we can improve in those areas so that it is easier for students to have that access to the professor's feedback since scheduling office hours meetings can be harder to do with virtual learning. But if it is worked into the class that could make it easier to get feedback on writing skills for each individual student.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if they are interested in Russia
I would recommend it as a great intro course to Russian Political Science.

Yes, I would highly recommend this class if you're interested in the field of comparative government and enhancing your knowledge of theories to compare states, their political history, government systems, and the role of the society in shaping state politics.
Yes! Definitely take this class if you are interested in Russian history and how it relates to other countries as well. It was really interesting so I highly recommend.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
